Roeddwn i'n mynd i fod yn fwyaf o'r ddwylo ffyrdd.
Roeddwn i'n mynd i ffyrdd o'r ddwylo ffyrdd i'r camp Iftynghyl.
Roeddwn i'n mynd i ffyrdd o'r ddwylo ffyrdd pan oeddwn i'n mynd i.
Ie.
Felly, nid oedd ymddygiad.
Roedd fy marn i'n gwybod bod angen i'w ddod o'r ddwylo oherwydd nad oedd yn gwneud hynny'n gael gwerth.
Mae'n ddiforol mewn amser i'w gwneud hynny'n gael gwerth.
Felly roeddwn i'n gwybod amgylcheddau,
a'r unrhyw beth yma oedd y camp Iftynghyl
sydd wedi'i ddyddio ar Ã´l y ddwylo,
a oedd angen i'r ddwylo yn y ddwylo.
Rwy'n gwybod bod amgylcheddau a'r marn i'n gael gwerth,
ac roedd nhw'n cael gwerth ar y ddwylo ymlaen at 7 Tunnel Junction.
Felly, roeddwn i'n mynd i'r hud Nysan,
a dyna lle roedd fy marn i'n gwybod yn 1949.
Yn ystod ymlaen,
roeddwn yn mynd i'r hud ymlaen,
y hud yma o'r ddwylo,
a'i gael ei gysylltu ei hun,
felly roeddwn yn dda i ddod i'r ddwylo ymlaen,
ar y ddwylo ymlaen,
a'r hynny'n bwysig.
Felly, beth yma o'r rhyw fath o'r hud yma?
Wel, roeddwn wedi mynd o'r ddwylo ymlaen,
i'r rhan bach.
Roedd fy marn i'n gael ymlaen
yn ystod y ddwylo ymlaen,
gyda'r ddwylo ymlaen,
i wneud y rhan bach ymlaen mwyaf,
a hefyd oherwydd ei fod yn gallu
i'n gallu startio ychwanegwyr yn y ddwylo.
Roeddwn yn eich hun yn ymwneud,
ond y gweithwyr ddim yn ychwanegwyr ei wneud hynny.
Felly, yn y hud, roedd hi wedi cael boxiau
a phethau fel barau o'r gwyb,
a chlwbau a phethau a phethau
ac mae'n bwysig bod pobl yn dod yn ystod
a dweud, a oes gennych chi unrhyw beth?
Felly roedd hi'n bwysig ei wneud hynny,
ond y ddwylo ymlaen nid oes rhywbeth,
ond unrhyw bach ymlaen.
Felly roedd y ddwylo ymlaen.
Yna roedd y goryddor llwybr
i'r ddwylo ar y ddwylo ymlaen,
sy'n cael ei ddwylo fel ychwanegwyr,
a byddai'n rhan bach.
Dwi ddim yn erbyn hynny'n dda iawn.
Dwi'n gwybod bod yna ddwylo nesaf.
Mae'n dda, mae'n dda,
ond dwi ddim yn erbyn beth yma.
Ond dwi ddim yn erbyn beth yma
oherwydd ydym wedi'i ddod yn y ddwylo ymlaen.
Mae'r ddau i'r ddwylo yma,
a'r radiu, a'r sofr, a'r cyffredin.
Ac yn ystod yna,
roedd y ddwy ddwylo ar y goryddor.
Felly roedd fy marn i'n cael un,
a phan a phan oedd yna.
Roedd hi'n un?
Do you remember feeling cold?
Yes, it wasn't warm, no, in a hut.
We had a black-lead grate,
so the fire had to be lit behind the grill every day,
and there was a big black-leaded oven at the side of it,
which you could bake in.
I don't know if my mother ever did.
It was quite primitive living really,
but I didn't know any different,
so I was perfectly happy.
My sister did push me.
We had to bath in a tin bath in front of this fireplace,
and my mother had the bath out,
and I got out of the bath.
My sister was ready to get in,
and she shoved me for some reason,
and I sat on the fire,
on the black-leaded thing.
So I had the most terrible burn
on my bottom and the top of my leg,
so I know I had to go to hospital
and have it dressed and all sorts of things,
and that's not so easy in those days
because nobody had a car to take you to a hospital.
Where was the hospital?
The hospital was the cottage hospital in Chepstow,
and I think, I'm not sure whether the museum is there now.
Yeah, it's become the museum.
Yes, and that used to be the hospital,
and I was in there when I was three or four
to have my tonsils out.
I remember my mother took me in,
and I had my own nightie on.
I had the operation in my nightie,
and when she came to fetch me a week later,
no visitors allowed because I was a child
and it would upset me.
So I was in a week, and when she came in,
I still had this bloody nightie on
from where they take the tonsils out.
But I do remember being on a lady's ward,
and there was one very nice old lady
that looked after me,
and she gave me a big bag of quality type sweets,
which was a great luxury when I went home.
I remember another lady in one of the corner beds,
and she was shrieking for the nurse all the time,
which I didn't quite understand what was going on.
It didn't seem to do me any harm.
How long did you actually live in these huts?
Till I was seven.
You were seven.
Yes, so we'd moved there in 1948.
My sister was born in 1949.
We moved to Caldecott in 1954,
and that's when the houses were built
in Caldecott and Port Scuwet.
And I think we could choose which place we went to,
but Dad chose Caldecott
because it was near a seven-tonne junction,
and he used to ride his bike to work,
so it was a quicker journey.
Where did you go to school then,
once you came to Caldecott?
Obviously I went to Port Scuwet School
when we were at the camp,
and I had to go on the bus to that
with all the other children.
It was too far to walk.
And then when we moved to Caldecott,
my first school was Church Road School,
which was the only school in Caldecott then.
But I wasn't there very long
because that was April 54.
The following year, I think,
I'm pretty certain that in 1955
the Green Lane School was open
because I have a photo
of the school class of 1955 taken there.
I was looking at it the other day,
so it must have been opened by 55.
That, of course, is now gone
and a brand new one in its place.
But we were the first wave.
And that became junior then,
and the old Church Road School became infants.
But there were no other schools
until the Comprehensive was built.
Children from here went to Rogget
for secondary education
or Larkfield for grammar school.
And you went to?
I went to Larkfield, yes.
So you've seen quite a lot of changes really.
A huge amount of changes, yes.
It's changed from a fairly small village
into not a large town,
but a small town with a lot of housing.
Huge housing estates.
Do you remember the impact?
Do you remember your parents talking about it?
Of the changes that were coming with it?
Not really, because I think it all developed so gradually.
When we moved into Longcroft Road,
Caerwmau Road was still being finished off.
The houses were there,
but they were still being finished.
Where the clinic is in Caerwmau Road,
that was the centre for the builders
to put all their buildings,
so it had water and railings all around it.
They kept all the building materials and stuff in there
while they were building the rest of the houses.
So we really were the first wave of newcomers to Caldecott.
So we were, a lot of the photos in this photos of old Caldecott book,
I remember that,
it still was very much a rural place, a village,
where Margaret's Way is,
was a field with a big pond in,
and we used to go and catch tadpoles and frogspawn in that.
Dewstow, we used to go and explore the quarry.
Well, I'm not quite sure how that's all worked out,
what was, but there's all houses there now anyway.
So do you remember anything about the schools,
what they were like?
Did you have plaque boards?
Did you have pen and ink?
Any of those details?
Yeah, I think when I first, yeah, when I was in junior school,
I think each desk had an inkwell in it,
and we had the pen you dipped in the inkwell.
I think so.
And blackboards and chalk, yes.
We had one teacher that I thought was really good fun
and always made jokes with him and all the rest of it,
and one day I drew his picture on the board
and put Mr Hodges, which wasn't like me
because I was a very good little girl,
and he made me stand on the chair
with my hands on my head after school.
So all the kids told my mother,
Mary's having to stand on the chair with her hands on her head,
and she thought it was hilarious.
She thought it was really funny because, you know,
I never usually put a foot wrong.
Yeah.
So he wasn't amused at that, so that taught me a lesson.
Yeah.
Do you remember any activities in the school?
Did you have...
Obviously you had the reading, writing and arithmetic.
Yes.
Like we all did.
By the time I was there, we did a lot of practice for the 11+.
Lots of intelligence tests and English tests and mental arithmetic,
and we did those a lot,
so that by the time you got to the 11+,
you were well versed in what you had to do.
I remember concerts because I remember doing choral speaking
when I was in the top class, I think,
and we had to say, hile bellox,
there was a boy whose name was Jim,
about Jim being eaten by the lion,
and I still remember that to this day.
I've often said it at different things,
and that was when I was 10 or 11.
Yeah, so that was nice.
And of course we had sports days.
And where were the sports?
Just in the school.
I remember being in the sack race,
and I remember being in the thread the needle race.
The trouble was I was really good in all the heats,
but when it came to the actual day, everything went wrong.
I think I was probably last in everything.
I'm not really a sporty person.
Better at gymnastics.
So you passed the 11+.
I passed the 11+, yeah.
I went to Larkfield.
And did you get there from Cardicot?
On the bus, the ordinary service bus, yes.
We were issued with season tickets by the County Council,
and I guess there were maybe a dozen of us from Cardicot.
Did you start noticing changes in the village by then?
Transport was improving, or perhaps?
Maybe you felt you had a car or something?
No, we never had a car really.
I did buy a car, which looked a bit like a hearse.
He bought it for Â£10.
It was a really ancient thing,
but he wanted to learn to drive on it.
But wherever he went, we mostly ended up pushing it back.
So he had to take some passengers in order for it to be pushed back afterwards.
And he used to keep it on the green down opposite our house,
and he'd sit in and practise changing gears and things.
So that was quite a joke for a while.
But he did pass his test eventually,
and mum and dad belonged to the Civil Defence in the 60s,
and they used to drive ambulances on exercise.
Well, mum didn't drive an ambulance, but dad did, and my aunt.
I'm just thinking of Cardicot.
One of the ladies we spoke to talked about cattle being driven through the centre of Cardicot.
That isn't something I remember, whether that was before my time, but I don't remember that.
What I remember going through Cardicot is the shale lorries for the steelworks being built.
And of course, the steelworks was responsible for a bigger increase in housing again,
and we had lots of people from the valleys.
And some of the friends I have that I've known since I was in the 60s are still here,
but they first came from Ebbw Vale of that area with the steelworks.
But there was a lot of complaints about the shale lorries,
because Cardicot was still a village, and all this going through was very dangerous.
And when you think what we have now, it was quite mild really.
Nothing like the great big lorries we get now. It's so enormous.
So I wonder where those shale lorries were coming from.
No, I'm not sure. I tend to think of them, well, they'd have had to go both ways,
they were going in the Chepstow direction, so I'm not sure whether there was anything that way.
It does suggest quarries on the Chepstow side.
Yeah.
Had they been going Newport way, of course, they wouldn't have come through Cardicot anyway,
so it has to be that way.
We didn't have the bypass road then, so they'd have had to go right through the village,
because none of Jubilee Way and all those were built,
and they weren't the quality or the size of the roads that they are now, they were much more lanes.
I'm sort of changing in demographics in a way.
The accents change, don't they?
Yes.
You hear the Welsh accent.
Yes, a bit more Welsh in it.
My accent, people have often been puzzled by it,
because it's got a touch of Bristol, a touch of Gloucester and a touch of Welsh.
So it's probably just a Monmouthshire accent.
And English was taught at school, just English?
Yes, yes, I never spoke Welsh.
I think my dad's granny used to speak Welsh.
He said if she wasn't speaking Welsh, she was speaking in tongues,
because she was a spiritualist, but he thinks it was Welsh.
She lived in Pontypool.
So presumably she was a Welsh speaker.
Let's grow you up then.
Good luck.
I was going to say, we did about the games last time, didn't we?
The sort of children's games and the entertainment we did.
I said we did hopscotch and just drew on the road,
because there wasn't much cars going by then, so we didn't get much interrupted.
Of course, the skipping ropes were an important part,
or doing things with a ball, throwing a ball about, hide and seek.
We also had the Saturday cinema in the YMCA hut on Church Road,
and that was run by the North family, who were very devout Pentecostals.
So they used to put on these cinema shows on a Saturday.
I think it might have been six months to go in.
I saw all sorts of really good films, and it had the seating,
but the back few rows were bus seats,
and all the courting couples sat on the bus seats at the back.
So I always aspired to get into these bus seats.
When I was engaged years later, my fiancÃ©e and I went to see South Pacific in that cinema,
and we sat in the bus seats at the back.
So I didn't get there in the end.
But Mr North, he'd say,
now there'll be a free ice lolly next week if you bring a friend,
or bring a friend and you'll get free ice lollies,
the walls ice lollies that were sort of triangular shaped.
Do you remember those long triangle things?
And then in the interval between the films, they'd have us singing choruses.
So we'd be singing,
And all these kids would be singing away, and they'd put the words up on the screen.
So really, it was a great outreach into the community for the church.
But nobody seemed to mind nowadays, they'd probably get lynched,
or forbidden to do it at the very least.
How much did that cost?
I think it was Â£10,000.
I think it was Â£6 to go in,
because I used to get a shill in a week pocket money,
which of course is Â£0.05 now.
So if I went to the cinema, it was a bit extravagant,
because I'd pay Â£6 to go in,
and then I'd get some sweets for thruppants,
and then I'd have thruppants left for the rest of the week.
Yeah, that's right.
We used to go into Mrs Dally's sweet shop on the cross,
because the cross then was a big roundabout, Cardicot Cross.
And Dally's had a little cottage on the corner,
the first you would come to on your left as you look at Newport Road.
And it had like a stable door to it,
so when she opened the shop, she'd just open the top half.
If she heard the bell go, she'd come out of her parlour to serve us,
and she got very impatient if you were too long choosing.
So we used to sort of hang over this door, seeing what she had on offer.
Sorry, I'm doing my best.
To see what was going on.
So do you remember any of the films that you saw?
I remember seeing Houdini.
That made a big impression on me,
because he got drowned in the end when he couldn't get out of his trappings.
So I remember that.
I remember lots and lots of cowboy films,
and I remember one where a cowboy had been scalped,
and he had this bright red head, and he'd been tied to his horse and came back.
I don't know what film it was,
but it made a big impression on me, because it was a bit horrible.
But I can't think what else I saw other than South Pacific, when I was much older.
So did you do any outings?
You went on holiday with your parents?
Yes, because Dad worked on the railway, we used to get free passes.
So I know we went over to Ireland on the ship the one day, crossed over there.
We didn't have cabins, we slept overnight in the hall, whatever it is, the Lenge.
So we'd enjoyed that, I think.
We went to Belfast, and we went up to Aberdeen,
and stayed with bed and breakfast with a Mrs Berry as the landlady.
What I do remember about a lot of holidays was it was often raining,
but I think that is so if you're holidaying Britain.
We went to Newquay and Ilfracom quite a bit,
and I remember my sister, she was only a baby really, and we were in the sun.
It was a lovely sunny holiday, which was probably why my parents weren't armed for it.
Margaret got a blister on her back, which was like a cushion, it was all blister, terrible.
So they took her to the doctor, and he really wiped the floor with my parents,
being so careless that they let her get in that state.
I think that was Ilfracom.
We used to camp in a tent when we went there.
Then my grandparents moved to London, where my grandad became a ticket collector.
We used to have holidays with them in London then, which was wonderful.
My mother would put me on in Newport, and my gran would meet us in London.
That was quite an adventure.
So Cardiff wasn't just a complete world then?
No, no, that's right.
I think with Dad having these free passes, we did go to a lot of different places,
usually only for a week at a time.
We went up to New Brighton, saw something with Liverpool.
We did very well, really.
Can I ask about when you went to the secondary school, to the grammar school, Larkfield?
Did you study Welsh? Was that part of the curriculum?
No, it wasn't then. It wasn't until the Welsh Language Act.
I don't know whether that was after the referendum,
or whether it was when we became the new counties in 1996.
But then the Act was passed that Welsh had to be taught in all of Monmouthshire schools.
Chepstow and Monmouth both tried to opt out, and they wouldn't let them,
because they said they were so Anglicised, and a lot of their pupils came from over the border.
But no, they have to teach it.
Of course, we've got more Welsh medium schools now anyway, haven't we?
Yes.
So what were the subjects that you did do that you remember?
English Language and Literature, French, Latin.
I think I might have started Latin in the second year.
History and Geography and General Science, Maths of course.
PE and Games.
And Needlework and Cookery.
And then that changed as you went through the school.
I think in the second year you could do Latin or Cookery, and I chose Latin.
And then it was Physics, Art or Needlework when you got to the third form, something like that.
I chose Needlework to do for GCE.
And the sciences, I chose Geology.
So I never really did Chemistry or Physics or Biology as separate subjects, only in the general sciences.
And then when I got to A levels, I did English-French and History.
So they were the subjects you liked the best, or you thought you would...?
Yes, that was what I liked. That was my scene.
And you went to college after that, didn't you?
Well, I had applied to university.
I had been wondering about the library, whether I would go and be a librarian.
I didn't get my grades as high as I should have done for my first choice, and I decided not to go to Clearing.
I passed the three, but not the grades I should have got.
So I decided that made up my mind, I was going to go to library school instead.
So I worked for a year and then went to Loughborough for two years.
That's where you trained to be a librarian.
I trained to be a librarian.
And then, not long after that, they made it a degree course.
So I did an open university degree in the 80s to sort of keep my qualifications abreast.
I was also nice to my mum and dad, because all through school my teachers had said,
Oh, Mary will go to university. She's a white, she'll go to university.
And I didn't, and I felt disappointed with them.
So when I did get my open university degree, they came down to the graduation and had a photo of me at last.
So you did your degree, your open university degree, as a mature student then?
Yes.
Were you married by then?
Oh, yes. The children were.
When I was doing it, Catherine was five or six because I know she had to do something for school at home.
And she had to watch something on the telly and she said, I'm going to be mummy doing her city.
Because I used to have to watch television programmes for her, you see.
She's going to be mummy doing her city.
And what subjects did you cover in your open university degree?
